gen:ReportedAttribute.com:Text: 4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education
4.2.2 Participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age), by sex

This indicator is defined as the percentage of children in the relevant age group (one year before the official lower basic school entry age) who are attending an early childhood education programme or lower basic school.

Organized learning is the combination of education and care designed with the intention of achieving pre-determined learning outcomes or the accomplishment of a specific set of educational task. Early childhood and primary education programmes are examples of organized learning programmes.

An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.

The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 years were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 years were oversampled. Hence, 13 households with children under 5 years and 12 households without children under 5 years were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

The sampling frame of Nepal is based on the 2011 National population and Housing Census (NPHC). The census frame is a complete list of all census wards created for the 2011 NPHC. At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. In designing the sample for the Nepal MICS, it was very useful to review the sample design and results of the MICS conducted in 2014, documented in the final report of that survey.

Therefore, a multi-stage, stratified cluster sampling approach was used for the selection of the survey sample. The primary sampling units (PSUs) selected at the first stage were the enumeration areas (EAs) defined for the census enumeration. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.
National official statistical agency that is responsible for conducting, survey and census.

The indicator measures children’s exposure to organized learning activities in the year prior to the start of primary school. A high value of the indicator shows a high degree of participation in organized learning immediately before the official entrance age to primary education.

The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on number of children in the relevant age group who participate in an organized learning programme and total number of children of same age range. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.

The number of children in the relevant age group who participate in an organized learning programme is expressed as a percentage of the total population in the same age range.

Participation rate in organized learning (one year before the official primary entry age) = Number of children in the relevant age group who participate in an organized learning programme / Total population in the same age range ×100

Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
It follows the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF.
Central Bureau of Statistics is the official agency to conducts survey and census. It has trained manpower

After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

Interviewer’s manual in Nepali language was developed which included concepts, definitions, description of each question and fieldwork procedures, etc. to ensure that quality information was collected.

Team supervisors were responsible for daily monitoring of filed work. It was mandatory to re-interview on one household per cluster. Furthermore, the skills and performance were observed on daily basis.
The data is available by province and rural and urban.
It follows MICS 6 guidelines of UNICEF and can be compared across countries.
Central Bureau of Statistics (CBS), 2020. Nepal Multiple Indicator Cluster Survey 2019, Survey Findings Report. Kathmandu, Nepal: Central Bureau of Statistics and UNICEF Nepal.
4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.4 By 2030, increase the number of youth and adults who have relevant skills, including technical and vocational skills, for employment, decent jobs and entrepreneurship
4.4.1 Proportion of youth and adults with information and communications technology (ICT) skills, by type of skill

This indicator is defined as the percentage of women and men (15 to 24 years) who have carried out at least one of nine specific computer related activities during the last 3 months. The indicator is expressed as a percentage.

The indicator on the proportion of individuals with ICT skills, by type of skills refers to individuals that have undertaken certain computer-related activities in the last three months.

Computer-related activities to measure ICT skills are as follows:

• Copying or moving a file or folder

• Using copy and paste tools to duplicate or move information within a document

• Sending e-mails with attached files (e.g. document, picture, video)

• Using basic arithmetic formulas in a spreadsheet

• Connecting and installing new devices (e.g. a modem, camera, printer)

• Finding, downloading, installing and configuring software

• Creating electronic presentations with presentation software (including images, sound, video or charts)

• Transferring files between a computer and other devices

• Writing a computer program using a specialized programming language

A computer refers to a desktop computer, a laptop (portable) computer or a tablet (or similar handheld computer). It does not include equipment with some embedded computing abilities, such as smart TV sets, and devices with telephony as their primary function, such as smartphones.

ICT skills determine the effective use of information and communication technology, so this indicator may therefore assist in making the link between ICT usage and impact. The lack of such skills continues to be one of the key barriers keeping people from fully benefitting from the potential of information and communication technologies. These data may be used to inform targeted policies to improve ICT skills, and thus contribute to an inclusive information society.

The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on total number of in-scope individuals (15 to 24 years) who have carried out each activity in the past 3 months, regardless of where that activity took place and total number of in-scope individuals. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.

This indicator is calculated as the proportion of in-scope individuals (15 to 24 years) who have carried out each activity in the past 3 months, regardless of where that activity took place. The indicator is expressed as a percentage.

Proportion of youth and adults with information and communication technology (ICT) skills, by type of skills = Number of individuals (15 to 24 years) who have carried each activity during 3 months, regardless of where that activity took place / Total number of people aged 15 to 24 years ×100

4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access

4.5.1 Parity indices (female/male, rural/urban, bottom/top wealth quintile and others such as disability status, indigenous peoples and conflict-affected, as data become available) for all education indicators on this list that can be disaggregated

This indicator shows net attendance ratio (adjusted) for girls divided by net attendance ratio (adjusted) for boys for area parity index for grade:

  1. Lower basic school (grade 1-5)
  2. Upper basic school (grade 6-8)
  3. Secondary school (grade 9-12)

Parity indices require data for the specific groups of interest. They represent the ratio of the indicator value for one group to that of the other. Typically, the likely more disadvantaged group is placed in the numerator. A value of exactly 1 indicates parity between the two groups.

To measure the general level of disparity between two sub-populations of interest with regard to a given indicator. The further from 1 the parity index lies, the greater the disparity between the two groups of interest.
The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.

The calculation for ANAR parity indices is presented below. Usually, group 1 is presumed to have the lowest ANAR and group 2 to have the highest, but it is not always the case. The following formula is used for calculation of area parity:

Where:

PRg1/g2= parity ratio of group 1 to group 2

ANARg1= ANAR of group 1

ANARg2= ANAR of group 2

Generally, when an index value falls between 0.97 and 1.03, it is regarded as parity between two groups. The further from 1.00 that a parity index lies, the greater the disparity between groups.

This indicator shows net attendance ratio (adjusted) for girls divided by net attendance ratio (adjusted) for boys for area parity index for grade:

  1. Lower basic school (grade 1-5)
  2. Upper basic school (grade 6-8)
  3. Secondary school (grade 9-12)

Parity indices require data for the specific groups of interest. They represent the ratio of the indicator value for one group to that of the other. Typically, the likely more disadvantaged group is placed in the numerator. A value of exactly 1 indicates parity between the two groups.

An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.

The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 years were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 years were oversampled. Hence, 13 households with children under 5 years and 12 households without children under 5 years were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access

4.5.1 Parity indices (female/male, rural/urban, bottom/top wealth quintile and others such as disability status, indigenous peoples and conflict-affected, as data become available) for all education indicators on this list that can be disaggregated

This indicator shows net attendance ratio (adjusted) for girls divided by net attendance ratio (adjusted) for boys for area parity index for grade:

  1. Lower basic school (grade 1-5)
  2. Upper basic school (grade 6-8)
  3. Secondary school (grade 9-12)

Parity indices require data for the specific groups of interest. They represent the ratio of the indicator value for one group to that of the other. Typically, the likely more disadvantaged group is placed in the numerator. A value of exactly 1 indicates parity between the two groups.

An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.

The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 years were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 years were oversampled. Hence, 13 households with children under 5 years and 12 households without children under 5 years were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

The sampling frame of Nepal is based on the 2011 National population and Housing Census (NPHC). The census frame is a complete list of all census wards created for the 2011 NPHC. At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. In designing the sample for the Nepal MICS, it was very useful to review the sample design and results of the MICS conducted in 2014, documented in the final report of that survey.

Therefore, a multi-stage, stratified cluster sampling approach was used for the selection of the survey sample. The primary sampling units (PSUs) selected at the first stage were the enumeration areas (EAs) defined for the census enumeration. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

Where:

PRg1/g2= parity ratio of group 1 to group 2

ANARg1= ANAR of group 1

ANARg2= ANAR of group 2

Generally, when an index value falls between 0.97 and 1.03, it is regarded as parity between two groups. The further from 1.00 that a parity index lies, the greater the disparity between groups.

4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.5 By 2030, eliminate gender disparities in education and ensure equal access

4.5.1 Parity indices (female/male, rural/urban, bottom/top wealth quintile and others such as disability status, indigenous peoples and conflict-affected, as data become available) for all education indicators on this list that can be disaggregated

This indicator shows net attendance ratio (adjusted) for girls divided by net attendance ratio (adjusted) for boys for area parity index for grade:

  1. Lower basic school (grade 1-5)
  2. Upper basic school (grade 6-8)
  3. Secondary school (grade 9-12)

Parity indices require data for the specific groups of interest. They represent the ratio of the indicator value for one group to that of the other. Typically, the likely more disadvantaged group is placed in the numerator. A value of exactly 1 indicates parity between the two groups.

An international multi-purpose household survey programme was developed by UNICEF in the 1990s to support countries in collecting internationally comparable data on a wide range of indicators on the situation of children and women, widely known as global MICS programme. It measures key indicators that allows countries to generate data for using in policy making and designing programs, and to monitor progress towards the national goals and global commitments.

The sample for the Nepal MICS 2019 was designed to provide estimates for a large number of indicators on the situation of children and women at the national level, for urban and rural areas and seven provinces. The urban and rural areas within each province were identified as the main sampling strata. Kathmandu valley urban is included as a separate stratum as it’s characteristics differ from the rest. Each stratum was a separate domain. The sample of household was selected in two stages. Within each stratum, at the first sampling stage a specified number of census enumerations areas (EA), was selected systematically with probability proportional to size. A household listing was carried out within the selected enumeration areas, identifying the households with and without children under 5 years. In total, 25 households with and without children under 5 years were selected in each sample enumeration area through systematic random sampling method. To ensure strong representativeness of children under 5 in the sample, household with children under 5 years were oversampled. Hence, 13 households with children under 5 years and 12 households without children under 5 years were selected from listing in each enumeration area. A total sample of 512 enumeration area and 12800 households was selected for the survey. As the sample is not self-weighting, sample weights are used for reporting survey results.

The sampling frame of Nepal is based on the 2011 National population and Housing Census (NPHC). The census frame is a complete list of all census wards created for the 2011 NPHC. At the time of last census, the urban household population constituted 20% of the total household population. According to the latest changes in the administrative structure, following the federalization of the government, the urban household population increased to 65%. CBS updated the population frame to reflect the current status. In designing the sample for the Nepal MICS, it was very useful to review the sample design and results of the MICS conducted in 2014, documented in the final report of that survey.

Therefore, a multi-stage, stratified cluster sampling approach was used for the selection of the survey sample. The primary sampling units (PSUs) selected at the first stage were the enumeration areas (EAs) defined for the census enumeration. A listing of households was conducted in each sample enumeration area, and a sample of households was selected at the second stage.

The questionnaires were developed based on the MICS 6 standard questionnaires of UNICEF. It was customized and translated into Nepali, Bhojpuri and Maithili language. After the development of questionnaire, it was pre-tested in Sindhupalchowk and Sindhuli district during March 2019. Based on the results of the pre-test, modifications were made to the wording and translation of the questionnaires.

4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.2 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys have access to quality early childhood development, care and pre-primary education so that they are ready for primary education
4.2.1 Proportion of children under 5 years of age who are developmentally on track in health, learning and psychosocial well-being, by sex

This indicator is defined as the percentage of children age 36-59 months who are developmentally on track in at least three of the following four domains: literacy-numeracy, physical, social-emotional, and learning.

Early childhood development (ECD) is very important process of human life to shape the future with opportunities. According to ‘Early Childhood Development Coming of Age: Science through the Life Course’, rapid brain development occurs during the first years of the life. The quality of children’s home environment and their interaction with caregivers play major role in the development of children during the time period. It also helps in boosting cognitive, physical, social and emotional development.

As per the UNICEF, a) on track for literacy and numeracy was classified as 1 if children aged 36-59 months could do at least two of the following tasks: 1) Identify or name at least 10 letters of the alphabet; read at least four simple, popular words and 2) Know the name and recognize the symbols of all numbers from 1 to 0; 0, otherwise

b) on track for physical development was classified as 1 if children aged 36-59 months could pick up a small object such as a stick or a rock from the ground with two of their fingers, and/ or the mother or caretaker did not indicate that the child was sometimes too sick to play; and 0 otherwise.

c) on track for socio-emotional development was classified as 1 for children aged 36-59 months for whom any of the following two were true: the child got along well with other children; the child did not kick, bite, or hit other children and the child did not get distracted easily; and o otherwise.

d) on track for learning was classifies as 1 children aged 36-59 months could follow simple directions on how to do something correctly and/or able to do given task independently; and 0 otherwise.

e) the overall ECD index was classified as 1 for children aged 36-59 months who were on track on at least three of the above four indicators; and 0 otherwise.

Early childhood development (ECD) is very important to shape one’s future. It is one of the most critical and cost-effective investments a country can make to improve adult health, education and productivity in order to build human capital for the upcoming future. ECD is equity from the start and provides a good indication of national development.

The calculation of this indicator requires to have reliable information on number of children aged 36 to 59 months who are developmentally on track in health, learning and psychosocial well-being and total number of children aged 36 to 59 months. The quality of such information is heavily dependent on the questionnaire design, the sample size and design and the accuracy of respondents' answers.

The number of children aged 36 to 59 months who are developmentally on track in health, learning and psychosocial well-being divided by the total number of children aged 36 to 59 months in the population multiplied by 100.

Proportion of children under 5 years of age who are developmentally on track in health, learning and psychosocial well-being = Number of children aged 36 to 59 months who are developmentally on track in health, learning and psychosocial well-being / Total number of children aged 36 to 59 months in the population ×100

4 Ensure inclusive and equitable quality education and promote lifelong learning opportunities for all
4.1 By 2030, ensure that all girls and boys complete free, equitable and quality primary and secondary education leading to relevant and effective learning outcomes

4.1.1 Proportion of children and young people: (a) in grades 2/3; (b) at the end of primary; and (c) at the end of lower secondary achieving at least a minimum proficiency level in (i) reading and (ii) mathematics, by sex

This indicator is defined as the percentage of children who successfully completed four foundational number tasks

(d) Age 7-14.

One of the most fundamental skills that a child can learn is the ability to read and understand the simple text. Learning outcomes are key indicators of quality education as they provide evidence on whether schools are equipping children with the foundational learning skills. Therefore, this indicator helps to measure learning outcomes expected for grades 2 and 3 in numeracy and reading among a children.

A strong foundation in basic numeracy skills during the early grades is crucial for success in mathematics in the later years. At present, mathematical skills are must require skills for all sorts of competitive job. According to report “School Readiness and Later Achievement’, early mathematical knowledge is a primary predictor of later academic achievement and future success in mathematics. It is related to an early and strong conceptual function. Foundational skills are divided into four tasks:

  1. Number reading
  2. Number discrimination
  3. Addition
  4. Pattern recognition

If the child succeeds in all four tasks above mentioned, s/he is considered to have foundational numeracy skills.

Over the past decades, access to education increased significantly. However, the disparities remain and many children in school struggle to achieve basic literacy and numeracy skills. Learning outcomes are key indicators of quality education as they provide evidence on whether schools are equipping children with the foundational learning skills. Therefore, this indicator helps to measure learning outcomes in numeracy and reading among children. It helps to capture a fuller picture of learning outcomes of children, including the disadvantaged, which helps ministries of education target support for children not learning to their potential.

A small proportion of interviewers across early MICS6 surveys in Nepal and elsewhere recorded the results of the two practise items in the data collection application, effectively shifting the responses in numeracy foundational skills questionnaire two spaces. During secondary editing such cases were identified and shifted back to the correct position, but the consequences remained of the loss of answers to the last two of the five pattern recognition items. The module has now been redesigned to avoid the occurrence of this problem.

While producing this report, several options were considered for presentation of the findings:

  1. Use all children in the table in MICS report. This would the best possible estimates on the tasks of number reading, number discrimination and addition, but underestimate on pattern recognition and, most importantly on the overall indicator of foundational numeracy skills.
  2. Exclude children affected by the shifted entries. This would impact all results in the tables, but the extent of the impact would need further analysis and depends largely on the amount and distribution of the excluded cases.
  3. Use a mixed approach, presenting number reading, number discrimination and addition for all children and the pattern recognition and overall indicator only on children not affected by the shifted entries, effectively using two denominators in the table.
  4. Not presenting the table and indicator as per methodology, reducing the requirement of successful completion in pattern recognition to three items rather than five. This would overestimate pattern recognition and the overall indicator compared to standard methodology.

Following analysis of the extent and distribution of shifted cases, option 2) was selected as score distributions of first three items of pattern recognition are very similar across shifted and non-shifted samples which indicates that excluding shifted cases would not affect overall average while addressing biases introduced by shifted cases.

Where,

FNSng = the share of children aged n and attending school grade g who have foundational numeracy skills

Numbskillng = children aged n and attending school grade g who have foundational numeracy skills equal to 1 according to the formula above

Tng­= total number of children aged n and attending school grade g

Proportion of children aged n years and attending school grade g who have foundational numeracy skills = Number of children aged n years and attending school grade g who have number skill equal to 1 according to the formula above / Total number of children aged n years and attending school grade g ×100
